awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Machine Learning in Cybersecurity
awd_abstract_narration:
This funding establishes a new Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at Pennsylvania State University.  An interdisciplinary team of experienced faculty mentors will guide undergraduate students in summer research projects focused on applying machine learning methods to solve cybersecurity problems, particularly cyber attacks.  The dramatic increase in the amount of data and complexity of data generated in sciences, government, and the business world and the increasing frequency of cyber-related attacks exploiting the vulnerabilities of the data, have made cybersecurity a critical national priority.  The site will recruit a cohort of 9 students each summer who will work on research projects that are challenging and important.  The project team will use a network of collaborators at Historically Black Colleges and Universities and at Hispanic-Serving Institutions to recruit students from under-represented minorities to participate in the REU Site. The students will also participate in other professional development that will help prepare them for graduate studies and careers in computing.  

The intellectual merit of this project lies in the focus on machine learning and cybersecurity and the strong faculty group guiding the research as well as the state-of-the art laboratory facilities the students will use.  As the amount and complexity of the digital footprints that cyber adversaries and attackers leave behind rapidly increase, defense mechanisms need to be able to handle and exploit the large amount of data to the fullest.  This site will work on important problems in this area and can potentially contribute to the body of knowledge of cybersecurity research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
This REU Site project at Penn State has successfully run a competitive 10-week-long summer program, titled as "Machine Learning in Cybersecurity” (1/1/2020--12/31/2023). The proposed theme lied at the intersection between Machine Learning and Cybersecurity fields. Each year, the program recruited capable undergraduate students nationwide and helped them conduct engaging and rewarding research projects on diverse problems in the proposed theme. The team included 10 tenure-track faculty members at Penn State—i.e., 1 PI, 1 Co-PI, and 8 Non-Co-PI Senior Personnel—with ample experiences in conducting top-quality research and supervising undergraduate students' research. In addition, collaborating faculty members from 5 HBCUs (Howard U., Tuskegee U., Bowie State U., Prairie View A&M U., North Carolina A&T State U.) and 3 HSIs (Polytechnic U. of Puerto Rico, Florida Int'l U., Cal State Long Beach) helped recruit underrepresented minorities and/or female students.

Our program provided students a valuable exposure to cybersecurity research exploiting a variety of data science and machine learning methods. The program has helped to increase the number and diversity of undergraduate students who would understand fundamental knowledge of machine learning and cybersecurity, and who wanted to continue their studies to graduate programs for advanced degrees. In the short term, the program will positively contribute to training undergraduate students in Penn State and other participating HBCU/HSI institutions. Our program successfully ran four times from 2020 to 2023 (2020 as a pilot due to COVID-19), training a total of 35 undergraduate students. While 34 (out of 35) students have successfully produced technical reports at the end of summer, some students went beyond our expectations and wrote top-tier conference publications as the first authors (e.g., full papers at AAMAS 2022 and AAAI 2024). Two students from the 2023 cohort are currently preparing their technical reports for the submission to the top-tier conferences around Dec. 2023. So far, per our follow-up monitoring, one student from the 2020 cohort (e.g., Ph.D. program in Johns Hopkins U.), five students from the 2021 cohort (e.g., M.S. program in NYU and UCSB, M.S. Fulbright program in Taiwan, and Ph.D. program in U. Wisconsin and Purdue) and one student from the 2022 cohort (e.g., Ph.D. program in WashU) have joined graduate programs.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/22/2024
Modified by: Dongwon Lee
